title: Forrest Classification of Upper GI Bleeding
description: Stratifies severity of upper GI bleeding according to endoscopic findings. Helps prognosticate and risk stratify patients, guides endoscopic therapeutic decisions, and assists in determining discharge versus inpatient monitoring.

parameters.name: endoscopic_finding
parameters.description: Endoscopic appearance of the bleeding peptic ulcer

result.name: forrest_class
result.description: Forrest classification category based on endoscopic findings

ranges.interpretation: Active arterial spurting from ulcer base. Highest risk category requiring immediate endoscopic intervention. Rebleeding risk: 55%, mortality risk: 11%. Emergency endoscopic therapy with injection, thermal coagulation, or mechanical therapy indicated.

Active oozing bleeding from ulcer without visible vessel. High risk category requiring endoscopic intervention. Rebleeding risk: 55%, mortality risk: 11%. Endoscopic therapy with injection or thermal coagulation recommended.
Non-bleeding visible vessel or protuberant pigmented spot. High risk of rebleeding. Rebleeding risk: 43%, mortality risk: 11%. Endoscopic therapy strongly recommended to prevent rebleeding.

Adherent clot overlying ulcer base. Intermediate risk of rebleeding. Rebleeding risk: 22%, mortality risk: 7%. Consider endoscopic therapy after clot removal or close monitoring with early intervention if rebleeding occurs.

Flat pigmented spot or hematin on ulcer base. Low risk of rebleeding. Rebleeding risk: 10%, mortality risk: 3%. Endoscopic therapy generally not required. Medical therapy and early discharge may be appropriate.

Clean ulcer base without stigmata of recent hemorrhage. Lowest risk category. Rebleeding risk: 5%, mortality risk: 2%. No endoscopic therapy required. Early discharge appropriate with medical therapy.

references: Forrest JA, Finlayson ND, Shearman DJ. Endoscopy in gastrointestinal bleeding. Lancet. 1974;2(7877):394-7.
Laine L, Peterson WL. Bleeding peptic ulcer. N Engl J Med. 1994;331(11):717-27.
Rockall TA, Logan RF, Devlin HB, Northfield TC. Risk assessment after acute upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage. Gut. 1996;38(3):316-21.
Sung JJ, Tsoi KK, Ma TK, Yung MY, Lau JY, Chiu PW. Causes of mortality in patients with peptic ulcer bleeding: a prospective cohort study of 10,428 cases. Am J Gastroenterol. 2010;105(1):84-9.
formula: Classification based on direct endoscopic visualization of ulcer appearance: Class 1A/1B (active bleeding), Class 2A/2B/2C (recent bleeding stigmata), Class 3 (clean base)
notes: Originally developed by Dr. John A. H. Forrest in 1974 based on 111 endoscopies
Classification is based on endoscopic appearance during upper endoscopy
Higher classes (1A, 1B, 2A) require urgent endoscopic intervention
Lower classes (2C, 3) may be managed conservatively with medical therapy
Rebleeding rates and mortality vary significantly between classes
Classification guides both therapeutic decisions and prognosis
Should be used in conjunction with clinical assessment and other risk factors
Class 2B (adherent clot) management remains somewhat controversial - some advocate for clot removal and treatment of underlying lesion
